articles.title: MARCH IN THE YEAR 1979
articles.summary: This document outlines a packed schedule of astronomical events and club activities for March and April 1979, with some notable events from late February. It details star parties, solar eclipse observations, lunar graze occultations, Messier Marathons, and various club meetings featuring talks and discussions. The listings provide dates, times, locations, and contact information for participants in the San Jose area.

articles.title: GRAZE INFORMATION
articles.summary: This document announces an IOTA expedition and invites SJAA members to observe a lunar graze of Aldebaran and other Hyades stars on the night of March 4-5, 1979, near Dixon, California. Participants are advised to bring binoculars, communicate via CB Channel 14 ('Graze Chasers'), and be ready by 11:40 PM PST for continuous recording starting at 12:07 AM PST. Instructions for location, weather updates, and communication are provided.

articles.title: Many Handy Numbers and Neat Stuff
articles.summary: This document provides a detailed list of astronomical data points, including various angles (graze position, vertex, cusp, Watts), celestial coordinates for a star and the Moon, and key times (sunset, twilight, moonset). It also includes information on star magnitude, spectrum, Moon elevation, illumination, and constellation, likely for planning or reporting a lunar graze event. Contact information for Jim Van Nuland is provided.

articles.title: Editorial
articles.summary: Penny E. Renshaw expresses profound gratitude for the positive feedback received on the February Bulletin, specifically thanking Dr. Gregory and Patrick Earhart for their encouraging calls. She also extends heartfelt thanks to all contributors for their valuable help, which significantly eased her workload and boosted her morale.

articles.title: BLURBS
articles.summary: This bulletin announces the combination of Astronomy Day with the general meeting, details an upcoming officers' banquet picnic, and schedules MDM star parties. It also mentions job openings at Kitt Peak National Observatory, a board resignation and replacement, and explains the bulletin's brevity due to the editor's eclipse travel plans, with a request for eclipse articles for the next issue. Finally, it provides Messier Marathon timings for observers.

articles.title: Open or Closed Universe
articles.summary: This article discusses the 'missing mass' problem, exploring whether there is sufficient mass to close the universe. Dr. Wallace Tucker presented a theory suggesting this missing mass exists as halos of stars, gas, and hot plasma in rich galaxy clusters, formed from galactic collisions. Recent X-ray observations from HEAO 1 support this, indicating that a universal hot plasma and massive dust/gas clouds could provide enough mass to close the universe.

articles.title: Sanborn Canyon star party - Jan. 27, 1979
articles.summary: This article recounts a star party held at Sanborn Canyon on January 27, 1979, attended by several astronomy enthusiasts. Despite very cold temperatures and poor seeing conditions that eventually brought clouds and an unexpected snowstorm, attendees managed to observe objects like Jupiter's red spot before most left early due to the weather.

articles.title: General Meeting by Cathy Pinheiro
articles.summary: The article reports on a well-attended general meeting held on February 3rd at the Rosicrucian Planetarium, where Jack Brode presented on 1950s-60s moon watch programs. Club president Gerry made numerous announcements, including upcoming Red Cross star parties focused on eclipse planning, an important Aldebaran graze, Astronomy Day plans, and dates for the Riverside Telescope Maker's Conference and the WAA conference. The article concludes with a 'Question of the Month' segment and answers regarding observing in the visible light spectrum.

articles.title: ELEMENTARY SCHOOL STAR PARTIES --
articles.summary: The article details several activities by the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA), including three elementary school star parties at Oak and Wilson Elementary Schools. These events engaged children and parents with telescope observations of celestial objects, educational presentations, and demonstrations of new astronomical imaging technology, notably Pete Manly's TV camera interface. Additionally, the article recounts a surprise indoor birthday party for member Kevin Medlock, featuring a clue-based scavenger hunt for his gift.

articles.title: February 17, 1979
articles.summary: This document from February 17, 1979, reports the discovery of Comet Kowal (1979a), a faint 17 magnitude object found by Charles Kowal using the 48" Schmidt telescope at Mt. Palomar. It also provides statistics on known comets and instructions to obtain the 'Catalogue of Cometary Orbits.' Additionally, the article includes community announcements, classified ads, and a call for members to donate to the American Red Cross due to the club's use of their building for indoor star parties.

articles.title: To the Editor:
articles.summary: This document features a letter to the editor by Bob Schalck, who expresses gratitude for a previous story and passionately encourages participation in telescope making, highlighting its community benefits and personal rewards. Complementing this, Jim Van Nuland provides a practical observing schedule detailing when Jupiter's Great Red Spot will be on the meridian for optimal viewing during March and early April.

articles.title: ASTRONOMY LENS
articles.summary: This document features an astronomy-themed crossword puzzle titled "Astronomy Lens." It displays a partially filled puzzle with astronomy-related terms and also provides answers to the previous month's "Sky Word # I" crossword puzzle.

articles.title: Life
articles.summary: The poem "Life" by Wolfgang Hanisch explores the profound origins of existence, depicting it as a mysterious spark emerging from emptiness and desire. It portrays a unifying "golden drop" that combines vast cosmic forces to ultimately bring about life. The document also contains a brief, seemingly unrelated note about a solar eclipse in February 1979, attributed to Bob Schalek.
